title: Are there any free colleges in England? - Quora

response.answer_text: If by the word college you mean university, only people ordinarily resident in Scotland don’t have to pay to go to university. People I the rest of the UK don’t get it for free, but don’t need to pay upfront either. UK graduates not from Scotland start repaying their tuition fees once they are earning just under £26000 per annum. In the UK the word college also means Further Education colleges, aimed at 16 to 19 year olds. Those colleges are free if you are British or ordinarily a resident of the UK and you are in that age group. The unemployed regardless of their age don’t need to pay to attend those colleges either.

Yes, almost all colleges in England are free. Colleges are where we study A levels (and other subjects) from 16 to 18 years of age before we go to university (which are currently not free). Some university, such as Oxford and Cambridge are also made up of colleges. As these are universitys they are not free.

The word you are looking for is colleges (no a in the word), not collages, and we in the UK call them universities. And no - apart from Scottish universities, for Scottish and EU (but not Welsh or English) students, there are no free universities in the UK, which means none in England.
